messages.body:
To Michael


Ah, very good. It appears we have much to discuss. I recommend that your read this ENTIRE message before you reply or make any assumptions. If you can do that, my friend, this could be a very good day for both of us.


First, let's be honest with each other. We both know that there are no "consignment boxes" and there are no millions on the way to Lou. You are running a scam and attempting to steal a little money from him. The good news is that the stupid old man actually believes you and is doing everything he can to send the $1200 to you. The bad news is that I have taken control of this situation and money will go to you only when I decide that it will. I already contacted the bank and, since I am the executor of a portion of Lou's estate, made sure that the transfer was cancelled. There is no money on the way to you and I am in control of this matter.


You should also know that, thanks to Lou's inability to scan and send a message to you, he gave me his gmail password and I've reviewed your whole conversation. Congratulations, he's completely convinced that there are boxes of money about to be sent to him. We both know that is not true.


The most important thing you should know is that Lou is an old, confused man. He is actually VERY wealthy and lives alone on a large estate on Molokai. He's not as poor as he led you to believe, but he does that. He's not well, his mind is weak and he is and easily influenced.


Why am I telling you this? Simple. I do not have access to all of Lou's wealth and I want us to work together to get to it. I know your game, where you constantly demand more and more money for the boxes that don't exist. If we become partners, I can assure you that I will make both of us very, very rich.


Are you smart and enough and bold enough for this plan? You have nothing to lose and a huge payday if you and I work together.

"Good morning to you and please do change the password of your email and don't give the money to your attorney and you don't let him know about this. messages.body:
To Michael


Yes, I've been to the bank and there may need to be a change of plans. Don't worry, you'll get your share, but the bank manager was very concerned and also quite suspicious of such a large transfer to Unibank. It appears that there is some sort of alert associated with fraud and money laundering and he had some very troubling questions.


Of course, we both know that's exactly what we're doing, so it shouldn't really be a surprise.


I'm currently sitting on $1,372,500 from our little project here, so your half is $686,250. Given the exchange rate to the Cedi (you ARE in Ghana, right?) this is a huge amount of money where you are.


As for me, I have several million more and am prepared to pack a couple bags and move on. My plan would be to stop in Ghana first and ensure that you get your money. Hell, I might even stay there if it's nice. I have a real weakness for African women.


Wiring or transferring that amount of money is looking entirely too dangerous, so we'll need to explore other options. A notarized cashier's check is the easiest and safest, but that would need to be written to your name and I'm quite certain it's not "Michael". I suppose I could make the cashier's check out to myself as well, but I would need to know a reputable bank to convert it to cash for us to divide.


Do you know such a bank? I can be on my way early next week and we can laugh at our fortunes over a cold beer.


Well done and I look forward to meeting you...and I am certain you want to see me.
